<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 487, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 571, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 729, 865]]<|/det|>
This document has 20 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<label>C</label>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 833, 201]]<|/det|>
measuring the moment used to turn a screw that is known to be about \(3 \times 10^{-6} \text{Nm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 544, 89]]<|/det|> Which statement about mass and weight is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 559, 117]]<|/det|> Mass is a property that causes change in motion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 134, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 625, 144]]<|/det|> Mass is caused by a gravitational field acting on a weight. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 134, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 566, 170]]<|/det|> Weight is a property that resists change in motion. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 134, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 630, 196]]<|/det|> Weight is caused by a gravitational field acting on a mass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 97, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 556, 241]]<|/det|> Which substance in the table has the lowest density? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 591, 381]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A cricket ball has a mass of \(0.16 \text{kg}\). The ball travels at \(30 \text{m/s}\). The ball is hit by a bat with a force of \(10 800 \text{N}\). After being hit, the ball moves off at \(30 \text{m/s}\) in the opposite direction.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 112, 601, 299]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 522, 329]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 382, 96, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 382, 571, 401]]<|/det|>
Electrical energy may be obtained from nuclear fission.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 413, 576, 432]]<|/det|>
In which order is the energy transferred in this process?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 133, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 443, 656, 462]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 472, 133, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 472, 656, 490]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 498, 133, 517]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 498, 656, 516]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 526, 133, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 526, 656, 544]]<|/det|>
nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 472, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 589, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 128, 796, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 332, 529, 351]]<|/det|>
The base area of P is equal to the base area of R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 510, 381]]<|/det|>
The base area of Q is larger than the other two.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 801, 411]]<|/det|>
Students are asked to compare the water pressure at the bottom of each container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 422, 846, 441]]<|/det|>
Student 1 says that the pressure at base R is more than the pressure at base P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 448, 839, 467]]<|/det|>
Student 2 says that the pressure at base Q is less than the pressure at base P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 475, 732, 494]]<|/det|>
Student 3 says that the pressures at all three bases are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 351, 522]]<|/det|>
Which students are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 291, 551]]<|/det|>
A none are correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 207, 577]]<|/det|>
B 1 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 585, 207, 603]]<|/det|>
C 2 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 611, 207, 628]]<|/det|>
D 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 655, 106, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 655, 504, 673]]<|/det|>
A liquid is evaporating. The liquid is not boiling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 685, 645, 702]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the liquid is correct at an instant in time?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 713, 134, 731]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 713, 626, 732]]<|/det|>
Any molecule can escape, and from any part of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 133, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 740, 648, 758]]<|/det|>
Any molecule can escape, but only from the liquid's surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 766, 133, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 766, 834, 785]]<|/det|>
Only molecules with enough energy can escape, and only from the liquid's surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 793, 133, 811]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 793, 804, 811]]<|/det|>
Only molecules with enough energy can escape, but from any part of the liquid.

The gas is kept at a constant pressure. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 297, 646]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 657, 688, 863]]<|/det|>

When he is further from the gully, he can neither hear nor see the stream. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 504, 732, 685]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 384, 718]]<|/det|> Which statement is not correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 730, 136, 747]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 728, 920, 761]]<|/det|> As he approaches the gully edge, he hears first the short wavelength, higher frequencies and then the long wavelength, lower frequencies. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 770, 134, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 770, 660, 787]]<|/det|> As he approaches the gully edge, the sound becomes louder. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 797, 134, 814]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 797, 660, 814]]<|/det|> He hears the stream because some of the sound is diffracted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 823, 134, 841]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 823, 920, 855]]<|/det|> He hears the stream because some of the sound is reflected from the opposite wall of the gully.

in airin glass
speed of ray\(v_{a}\)\(v_{g}\)
wavelength of ray\(\lambda _{a}\)\(\lambda _{g}\)
frequency of ray\(f_{a}\)\(f_{g}\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 843, 482]]<|/det|> Three suggestions as to how the refractive index of glass \(n\) may be calculated are listed. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 496, 285, 533]]<|/det|> \[1\quad n = \frac{\nu_{a}}{\nu_{g}}\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 542, 285, 579]]<|/det|> \[2\quad n = \frac{\lambda_{a}}{\lambda_{g}}\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 588, 285, 625]]<|/det|> \[3\quad n = \frac{f_{a}}{f_{g}}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 640, 379, 658]]<|/det|> Which suggestions are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 668, 134, 687]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 668, 240, 687]]<|/det|> 1, 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 668, 303, 687]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 668, 425, 687]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 668, 470, 687]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 668, 593, 687]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 668, 636, 687]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 668, 710, 687]]<|/det|> 2 and 3 only

<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 70, 729, 91]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows the current–voltage characteristic for a filament lamp?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 98, 905, 235]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 262, 107, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 262, 598, 284]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show pairs of circuits containing logic gates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 293, 870, 313]]<|/det|>
In which diagram does the lower circuit of the pair behave differently from the upper circuit?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 320, 765, 631]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 657, 104, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 657, 752, 677]]<|/det|>
Two \(3.0 \Omega\) resistors and one \(6.0 \Omega\) resistor are connected in series with a cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 348, 707]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 717, 133, 735]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 717, 648, 736]]<|/det|>
The current in the cell is equal to the current in the resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 133, 762]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 744, 682, 762]]<|/det|>
The current in the cell is greater than the current in the resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 771, 133, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 771, 853, 789]]<|/det|>
The potential difference (p.d.) across each resistor is equal to the p.d. across the cell.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 133, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 797, 616, 816]]<|/det|>
The potential differences across each resistor are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 675, 91]]<|/det|>
Two resistors, with resistances \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\), are connected in parallel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 541, 121]]<|/det|>
The resistance \(R_{1}\) is greater than the resistance \(R_{2}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 129, 616, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 233, 534, 252]]<|/det|>
What is the resistance of the parallel combination?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 262, 134, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 262, 354, 280]]<|/det|>
less than either \(R_{1}\) or \(R_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 288, 134, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 247, 306]]<|/det|>
equal to \(R_{1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 134, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 314, 247, 332]]<|/det|>
equal to \(R_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 341, 134, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 341, 361, 359]]<|/det|>
the average of \(R_{1}\) and \(R_{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 384, 106, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 779, 402]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers and fuses are devices used to protect a circuit from overloading.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 850, 432]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly describes the difference between a circuit breaker and a fuse?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 131, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 443, 767, 460]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers can be reset if they operate but fuses need to be replaced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 131, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 470, 767, 488]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers need to be replaced if they operate but fuses can be reset.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 129, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 496, 670, 514]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers can be used in an a.c. circuit but fuses cannot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 131, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 523, 670, 541]]<|/det|>
Circuit breakers cannot be used in an a.c. circuit but fuses can.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 566, 104, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 566, 677, 584]]<|/det|>
Electrical energy is transferred by transmission lines at high voltage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 596, 564, 613]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains why a high voltage is used?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 624, 131, 642]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 624, 368, 642]]<|/det|>
The voltage is alternating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 651, 131, 669]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 651, 546, 668]]<|/det|>
The transmission lines have a larger resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 678, 131, 696]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 678, 510, 695]]<|/det|>
The transmission lines carry greater power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 704, 133, 722]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 704, 737, 720]]<|/det|>
There is a smaller current in the transmission lines for the same power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 787, 91]]<|/det|> Which diagram shows the magnetic field around a straight, current-carrying wire? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 98, 897, 350]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 373, 106, 390]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 636, 392]]<|/det|> The coil in a d.c. motor is connected to a split-ring commutator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 403, 526, 422]]<|/det|> What is the purpose of the split-ring commutator? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 134, 450]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 432, 667, 450]]<|/det|> to ensure that the coil continues to rotate in the same direction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 134, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 459, 683, 477]]<|/det|> to ensure that the size of the current in the coil remains constant <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 134, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 485, 740, 504]]<|/det|> to ensure that the size of the turning effect on the coil remains constant <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 511, 134, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 511, 653, 529]]<|/det|> to ensure that the turning effect on the coil changes direction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 555, 106, 573]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 920, 590]]<|/det|> The nucleus of an americium atom contains 146 neutrons and 95 protons. It decays by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 920, 635]]<|/det|> How many neutrons and how many protons remain in the nucleus when this form of americium decays? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 645, 541, 791]]<|/det|>
number of neutrons remainingnumber of protons remaining
A14293
B14295
C14493
D14495

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 160, 272, 178]]<|/det|>
105 000 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 186, 128, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 186, 272, 203]]<|/det|>
157 500 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 128, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 212, 272, 230]]<|/det|>
210 000 years

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 238, 272, 255]]<|/det|>
420 000 years

<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 376, 301]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 758, 215, 776]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 758, 298, 776]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Of the three types of ionising radiation, \(\alpha\) , \(\beta\) and \(\gamma\), why does \(\alpha \text{- emission}\) cause the most ionisation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 134, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 116, 445, 135]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) - particles have the smallest mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 144, 133, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 445, 163]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) - particles have the greatest mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 131, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 171, 494, 190]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) - particles move with the greatest speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 133, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 198, 551, 217]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) - particles travel the greatest distance in matter.
